articles.title: Seeding opportunities for Black atmospheric scientists
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04068-3Vernon Morris inspires change in the geoscience community by calling on colleagues to commit to anti-racism in their scientific endeavours.
articles.content:
Vernon Morris (outlined) with alumni from the atmospheric sciences PhD programme he established at Howard University in Washington DC.Credit: Vernon Morris

Changemakers This Nature Q&A series celebrates individuals who have fought racism in science and who champion inclusion. The series often highlights initiatives that could be applied to other scientific workplaces.

When Vernon Morris earned his doctorate in Earth and atmospheric sciences in 1991 from the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, he was the first African American to do so, joining fewer than a dozen other Black atmospheric sciences PhD holders in the United States at that time.

From the get-go, Morris knew that something needed to change to create more opportunities for Black scientists in his field. In 2001, as a professor at Howard University in Washington DC, he became founding director of the first PhD-granting graduate programme in atmospheric sciences at a historically Black college and university (HBCU). Between 2006 and 2018, that programme produced at least 50% of African American and 30% of Latinx PhD graduates in atmospheric sciences in the United States.

A specialist in airborne particle processes, Morris studies long-range transport of mineral dust from desert regions and densely populated areas, such as megacities. His team’s work feeds into global and regional models of weather and climate that are used to make predictions in forecast models for hurricanes and tropical storms.

I encourage women to claim their space in astrophysics and beyond

For example, Morris studies microbial populations found on grains of desert sand transported from Africa to the Caribbean, and then on to the continental United States and South America. “We’re finding fairly rich microbial populations on those” grains, he says, and the populations “change as the surface chemistry changes”. These microorganisms can affect ecosystem health in the oceans or in soils where they are deposited, he notes. Understanding particle transport “can have domino effects in how we understand biogeochemistry and microbial exchange between continents”, he says.

Morris is now an associate dean for knowledge enterprise and strategic outcomes at Arizona State University in Tempe. Much as with particle transport, his influence on younger generations of scientists is far-reaching.

In 2023, Morris received the American Geophysical Union’s Lifetime Achievement Award for Diversity and Inclusion. He was recognized for having mentored more than 200 students and geoscientists of colour and for creating partnerships that benefited at least 1,000 undergraduate and graduate students. What’s more, he initiated No Time for Silence, a collaborative call to action for anti-racism in the geoscience community. Morris spoke to Nature about chasing dust storms and why science needs intellectual activists now more than ever.

What’s the coolest discovery or surprise that has occurred in your research?

Our understanding of aerosols has evolved a lot since I was a graduate student. At that time, researchers thought that aerosols didn’t even react. The particles might as well have been billiard balls moving back and forth, and were not thought to linger in the atmosphere long enough to affect any chemistry.

I had my white colleagues walk in a Black student’s shoes for a day

What we have found since is that the higher the resolution with which you can probe particles in the atmosphere, the more you can learn about them.

The fact that you have active microbial communities in dust storms was not known at the beginning of my career. A lot of the theories said that the microbes would die instead of being transported, because there’s too much radiation in the atmosphere and not enough moisture. There were all sorts of rationales that had nothing to do with direct observation.

We focused a lot of effort on going into and tracking dust storms in situ, and taking detailed measurements. We found from direct observations that a lot of the assumptions were just wrong.

How do you deal with criticism of your diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) and anti-racism work?

I have always encountered criticism and scepticism with regards to inclusive practice. I have never allowed uninformed criticism to dictate my response, behaviour or expectations of the outcomes of my efforts.

But the criticism has been pretty constant.

Established leaders in the field were actively against setting up a graduate programme in atmospheric science at Howard. At the time, we were being actively challenged about whether there was significant interest in minoritized communities. Most of the established PhD programmes in atmospheric sciences had never admitted, let alone graduated, more than two African American, Puerto Rican or Native American students. I also think that we were suffering from a ‘three strikes’ prejudicial cynicism: we were all junior faculty members, we were all people of colour and we were at an HBCU, and not an exclusive research university. We were challenged by our critics to find 50 ‘competitive’ graduate students from minoritized communities. We found more than 200, all of whom attended a National Science Foundation-sponsored workshop at Howard.

The financial shackling of historically Black universities in the United States

There’s always pushback. When I give talks focused on critical analysis of data to show that there’s discrimination or racialization in certain practices and privileges in the scientific community, I’ve had people try to disrupt my presentations. When that happens, it’s mostly on me to stop the disruption because other people don’t usually intervene.

But I was bussed to school, aged 7, as part of efforts to reduce segregation by moving pupils around, and people were spitting at us and throwing trash. My parents were lifelong activists who led strikes, marches and protests. As an undergraduate in the 1980s, I took part in civil-rights demonstrations in Forsyth County, Georgia, at which people were hit in the head with rocks and bottles. I worked for the Voter Education Project in South Georgia to register Black and rural voters, and was literally run out of town. I’ve seen how bad it can get.

So, if someone’s trying to ask me a ‘gotcha’ question at a conference or a talk, it’s typically not going to get worse than that. It’s aimed at trying to intimidate or silence me, and I don’t intimidate easily.

What advice would you give to a 20-something researcher in your field?

Try to find the enjoyment in the creation or advancement of knowledge. Relishing the life of the mind is important. Don’t let someone else define your success for you.

It also covers his mentorship of hundreds of students and his leadership in anti-racism initiatives within the geoscience community. This represents a meaningful, broad societal benefit by promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEM, with detailed context and measurable outcomes.
articles.personality_title: Vernon Morris opens doors for Black scientists in atmospheric research
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Vernon Morris was the first African American to earn a PhD in Earth and atmospheric sciences in 1991. At that time, very few Black scientists worked in this field, and opportunities for them were limited.

**What happened** – In 2001, Morris started the first PhD program in atmospheric sciences at Howard University, a historically Black college. This program has helped produce half of all African American and nearly a third of all Latinx PhD graduates in this science in the US between 2006 and 2018. Morris also studies how dust and tiny particles travel through the air, affecting weather and ecosystems.

**Impact** – Morris’s program gave many minority students a chance to study and succeed in atmospheric sciences, a field where they were previously underrepresented. His research helps improve weather forecasts and shows how dust can carry microbes across continents, affecting the environment in surprising ways. He has mentored over 200 students of color and worked to fight racism in science.

**What's next step** – Morris continues to lead efforts for diversity and inclusion at Arizona State University. His anti-racism initiative, called No Time for Silence, invites scientists to actively support fairness in their work. The program at Howard University serves as a model that other schools might follow to increase diversity in STEM fields.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Vernon Morris has transformed atmospheric science by creating educational opportunities for Black scientists and leading research that connects air particles to global environmental health.
articles.personality_title_fr: Vernon Morris ouvre des portes aux scientifiques noirs en sciences atmosphériques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Vernon Morris a été le premier Afro-Américain à obtenir un doctorat en sciences de la Terre et de l’atmosphère en 1991. À cette époque, très peu de scientifiques noirs travaillaient dans ce domaine et les opportunités étaient limitées.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2001, Morris a lancé le premier programme de doctorat en sciences atmosphériques à l’Université Howard, une université historiquement noire. Ce programme a aidé à former la moitié des doctorants afro-américains et près d’un tiers des doctorants latinxs aux États-Unis entre 2006 et 2018. Morris étudie aussi comment la poussière et les petites particules voyagent dans l’air, affectant le climat et les écosystèmes.

**Impact** – Le programme de Morris a donné à de nombreux étudiants issus de minorités la chance d’étudier et de réussir dans un domaine où ils étaient peu représentés. Ses recherches améliorent les prévisions météorologiques et montrent comment la poussière peut transporter des microbes à travers les continents, influençant l’environnement de manière surprenante. Il a encadré plus de 200 étudiants de couleur et lutte contre le racisme dans la science.

**Prochaine étape** – Morris continue de promouvoir la diversité et l’inclusion à l’Université d’État de l’Arizona. Son initiative antiraciste, No Time for Silence, invite les scientifiques à soutenir activement l’équité dans leur travail. Le programme de l’Université Howard sert de modèle que d’autres universités pourraient suivre pour augmenter la diversité dans les sciences.

**En une phrase** – Vernon Morris a transformé les sciences atmosphériques en créant des opportunités éducatives pour les scientifiques noirs et en menant des recherches reliant les particules de l’air à la santé environnementale mondiale.
articles.personality_title_es: Vernon Morris abre puertas para científicos negros en la investigación atmosférica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Vernon Morris fue el primer afroamericano en obtener un doctorado en ciencias de la Tierra y la atmósfera en 1991. En ese momento, muy pocos científicos negros trabajaban en este campo y las oportunidades para ellos eran limitadas.

**Qué pasó** – En 2001, Morris creó el primer programa de doctorado en ciencias atmosféricas en la Universidad Howard, una universidad históricamente negra. Este programa ayudó a formar a la mitad de los graduados afroamericanos y a casi un tercio de los estudiantes Latinx con doctorado en esta ciencia en Estados Unidos entre 2006 y 2018. Morris también estudia cómo el polvo y las partículas viajan por el aire, afectando el clima y los ecosistemas.

**Impacto** – El programa de Morris dio a muchos estudiantes de minorías la oportunidad de estudiar y triunfar en un campo donde estaban poco representados. Su investigación ayuda a mejorar los pronósticos del clima y muestra cómo el polvo puede transportar microbios entre continentes, afectando el medio ambiente de maneras inesperadas. Ha mentoreado a más de 200 estudiantes de color y lucha contra el racismo en la ciencia.

**Próximo paso** – Morris sigue liderando esfuerzos para la diversidad e inclusión en la Universidad Estatal de Arizona. Su iniciativa antirracista, llamada No Time for Silence, invita a los científicos a apoyar activamente la justicia en su trabajo. El programa en la Universidad Howard sirve como modelo que otras escuelas podrían seguir para aumentar la diversidad en las ciencias.

**Una frase clave** – Vernon Morris ha transformado la ciencia atmosférica creando oportunidades educativas para científicos negros y liderando investigaciones que conectan las partículas del aire con la salud ambiental global.

articles.title: “EU4InclusiveTeaching”, over 15,000 teachers trained in inclusive teaching
articles.summary: The project, aiming to strengthen education in Albania by investing in teachers, support services, and the system itself in parallel, lays sustainable foundations for long-term inclusion.
articles.content:
The project, aiming to strengthen education in Albania by investing in teachers, support services, and the system itself in parallel, lays sustainable foundations for long-term inclusion.

Inclusive education is the way that ensures every child has the space and support to learn and grow as they deserve.

This principle has been the core of the “EU4InclusiveTeaching” project in Albania, financed by the European Union to strengthen pre-university education, launched in 2022 with a budget of 2.3 million euros.

The results achieved so far by the project were discussed at the “Stories of Inclusion” event, where the focus was also broadened regarding the journey and achievements of “EU4InclusiveTeaching”.

The project, which aims to strengthen education in Albania by investing in teachers, support services and the system itself in parallel, lays sustainable foundations for long-term inclusion.

During this project, 15,000 teachers have been trained in inclusive teaching; 348 trainers have been certified to spread this approach at the national level; 550 psycho-social cabinets have been equipped with modern infrastructure; two special schools have been transformed into National Resource Centers.

The project has enabled direct benefits for over 135,000 children through more inclusive learning practices.

The European Union, together with Albanian partners and institutions, continues to support an education where no one is left behind, in line with European standards and the priorities of the integration process. (23 December)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant and well-funded initiative to promote inclusive education in Albania, training a large number of teachers and improving infrastructure to ensure equitable learning opportunities for over 135,000 children. This has broad societal impact by fostering inclusion and equal rights in education, supported by detailed context and measurable outcomes.
articles.personality_title: Over 15,000 Albanian teachers trained to support inclusive education
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Inclusive education means making sure every child can learn and grow with the support they need. In Albania, a project called “EU4InclusiveTeaching” started in 2022 to improve schools by helping teachers, support services, and the education system.

**What happened** – Funded by the European Union with 2.3 million euros, the project trained 15,000 teachers in inclusive teaching methods. It also certified 348 trainers to spread these methods nationwide, upgraded 550 psycho-social support offices with modern tools, and turned two special schools into National Resource Centers. These efforts have helped more than 135,000 children learn in a more supportive environment.

**Impact** – This project is important because it doesn’t just help teachers but also improves the whole system, making long-term inclusion possible. By training so many teachers and improving support services, children with different learning needs can get better education and feel more included in their schools.

**What's next step** – The European Union and Albanian partners plan to keep supporting inclusive education. They want to continue improving schools so no child is left behind, following European standards and helping Albania move closer to joining the EU.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU-funded project has trained thousands of teachers and improved schools in Albania to create a more inclusive education system that benefits over 135,000 children.

Il a aussi certifié 348 formateurs pour diffuser ces méthodes dans tout le pays, modernisé 550 bureaux de soutien psycho-social, et transformé deux écoles spécialisées en Centres Nationaux de Ressources. Ces efforts ont aidé plus de 135 000 enfants à apprendre dans un environnement plus adapté.

En formant autant d’enseignants et en renforçant les services de soutien, les enfants avec des besoins différents peuvent mieux apprendre et se sentir plus intégrés.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le projet financé par l’UE a formé des milliers d’enseignants et amélioré les écoles en Albanie pour créer un système éducatif plus inclusif qui profite à plus de 135 000 enfants.

articles.title: Affordable housing: EU Commissioner Jørgensen sees Vienna as a model
articles.summary: EU Commissioner Dan Jørgensen is to combat the housing crisis in Europe. At a meeting with Mayor Michael Ludwig, he praised Vienna’s housing policy. Both consider short-term rentals for tourist purposes to be a problem.
articles.content:
EU Commissioner Dan Jørgensen is to combat the housing crisis in Europe. At a meeting with Mayor Michael Ludwig, he praised Vienna’s housing policy. Both consider short-term rentals for tourist purposes to be a problem.

Vienna (APA) – The EU Commissioner for Energy and Housing, the Dane Dan Jørgensen, on Friday described Vienna’s housing policy as a model. It could serve as an inspiration for other cities, he said after a meeting with Vienna’s mayor Michael Ludwig – at which Jørgensen presented the EU plan for affordable housing. Europe is facing a housing crisis that is also a social crisis, the EU Commissioner warned.

So far, the issue has not been particularly high on the agenda of the European Union, the guest emphasized. That has now changed. After all, millions of citizens are affected and cannot live in adequate housing. For example, everyone should be able to live near their place of work, which is becoming increasingly difficult in many cities.

Creating housing as a challenge

“The EU is also there for people’s concerns,” Jørgensen assured. When it comes to housing, Vienna has been a model for more than 100 years. Mayor Ludwig, in turn, expressed his satisfaction that the EU is taking up the issue and has now also set up a department for it. The Commission’s plan for affordable housing is also important: “It is a first strong move.”

Jørgensen and Ludwig agreed that, above all, the creation of housing – even in times of tight budgets – is necessary. According to the EU Commission, around 650,000 apartments would have to be built in the Union in addition to the current level of around 1.6 million units. The additional properties would cost around 150 billion euros, it was said today.

No privatizations in Vienna

The mayor further reaffirmed that there are no plans for privatizations. No municipal apartments are being sold; instead, new ones are even being built, he stressed. In addition, it is also about creating framework conditions for the commercial sector.

Both considered short-term rentals of apartments for tourist purposes to be a problem. Ludwig expressed his conviction that Vienna is also setting a good example here. He pointed out that apartments may only be offered on the platforms for a maximum of 90 days per year.

With regard to a possible vacancy tax, however, he was skeptical. Expectations should not be set too high here. It is difficult to check or define vacancy, Ludwig cautioned. (19.12.2025)

The editorial responsibility for publication lies with APA.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the EU's concrete plans and commitments to address the widespread housing crisis affecting millions, highlighting Vienna's successful model of affordable housing as inspiration. It discusses tangible policy actions, budget considerations, and the social importance of housing, which has broad societal impact and offers hope for improved living conditions across Europe.
articles.personality_title: EU highlights Vienna’s housing model to tackle Europe’s housing crisis
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Europe is facing a serious housing crisis where many people struggle to find affordable places to live near their jobs. This problem affects millions and has become an important social issue.

**What happened** – Dan Jørgensen, the EU Commissioner responsible for energy and housing, visited Vienna and praised the city’s long-standing housing policies. He met with Vienna’s mayor, Michael Ludwig, and presented the EU’s new plan to build more affordable homes across Europe. They both agreed that short-term rental apartments used by tourists cause problems for housing availability.

**Impact** – Vienna has been successfully providing affordable housing for over 100 years without selling off public apartments. This makes the city a strong example for others. The EU plans to build an extra 650,000 apartments, which would cost about 150 billion euros. This shows a serious commitment to solving housing shortages across many cities.

**What’s next step** – The EU will work on building more homes and creating rules to support affordable housing. Vienna will continue limiting short-term rentals to 90 days per year to keep apartments available for residents. The EU’s focus on housing is new but growing, and it could lead to better living options for many people in Europe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is turning to Vienna’s proven housing policies as a guide to create more affordable homes and address Europe’s housing crisis.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE met en avant le modèle de Vienne pour résoudre la crise du logement en Europe
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Europe fait face à une grave crise du logement où de nombreuses personnes ont du mal à trouver des logements abordables près de leur travail. Ce problème touche des millions de personnes et devient un enjeu social important.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Dan Jørgensen, commissaire européen chargé de l’énergie et du logement, a visité Vienne et a salué la politique de logement de la ville, en place depuis longtemps. Il a rencontré le maire Michael Ludwig et présenté le nouveau plan de l’UE pour construire plus de logements abordables en Europe. Ils ont convenu que les locations touristiques de courte durée posent problème.

**Impact** – Vienne fournit depuis plus de 100 ans des logements abordables sans vendre les appartements publics, ce qui en fait un exemple solide pour d’autres villes. L’UE prévoit de construire 650 000 appartements supplémentaires, pour un coût d’environ 150 milliards d’euros. Cela montre un engagement sérieux à résoudre les pénuries de logements.

**Prochaines étapes** – L’UE travaillera à construire plus de logements et à créer des règles pour soutenir le logement abordable. Vienne continuera de limiter les locations touristiques à 90 jours par an pour garder des logements pour ses habitants. L’attention de l’UE sur le logement est nouvelle mais grandissante, ce qui pourrait améliorer les conditions de vie.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – L’UE s’inspire des politiques de logement éprouvées de Vienne pour créer plus de logements abordables et lutter contre la crise du logement en Europe.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE destaca el modelo de Viena para enfrentar la crisis de vivienda en Europa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Europa enfrenta una grave crisis de vivienda donde muchas personas tienen dificultades para encontrar hogares asequibles cerca de su trabajo. Este problema afecta a millones y se ha convertido en un asunto social importante.

**Qué pasó** – Dan Jørgensen, comisario europeo de energía y vivienda, visitó Viena y elogió las políticas de vivienda de la ciudad que existen desde hace mucho tiempo. Se reunió con el alcalde Michael Ludwig y presentó el nuevo plan de la UE para construir más viviendas asequibles en Europa. Ambos coincidieron en que los alquileres turísticos de corta duración son un problema.

**Impacto** – Viena ha estado proporcionando viviendas asequibles durante más de 100 años sin vender apartamentos públicos, lo que la convierte en un ejemplo fuerte para otras ciudades. La UE planea construir 650,000 apartamentos adicionales, con un costo de unos 150 mil millones de euros. Esto muestra un compromiso serio para resolver la escasez de viviendas.

**Próximos pasos** – La UE trabajará para construir más viviendas y crear reglas que apoyen la vivienda asequible. Viena seguirá limitando los alquileres turísticos a 90 días al año para mantener viviendas disponibles para residentes. El enfoque de la UE en la vivienda es nuevo pero está creciendo, lo que podría mejorar las opciones de vivienda para muchas personas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La UE toma como guía las políticas de vivienda exitosas de Viena para crear más viviendas asequibles y enfrentar la crisis de vivienda en Europa.

articles.title: EU transfers further billions in aid to Ukraine
articles.summary: For almost four years, Russia has been attacking Ukraine. The EU has been supporting Kyiv since the beginning of the war – now more billions are flowing.
articles.content:
For almost four years, Russia has been attacking Ukraine. The EU has been supporting Kyiv since the beginning of the war – now more billions are flowing.

Brussels (dpa) – Ukraine, which has been attacked by Russia, has received further financial aid from the EU amounting to 2.3 billion euros. This is intended to support the country’s public finances and public administration, as announced by the European Commission.

Ukraine has now been defending itself for almost four years against the Russian war of aggression.

Since the beginning of the Russian invasion in February 2022, the EU and its member states have pledged aid in the three-digit billions – from military and financial support to assistance for refugees.

The so-called Ukraine Facility of the EU alone is endowed with 50 billion euros. Through the so-called Era Initiative, around 18.1 billion euros are being provided by the European Union. For this, interest income from the custody of frozen Russian state assets in the EU is being used. (22 December)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on significant financial aid from the EU to Ukraine, supporting the country's public finances and administration amidst ongoing conflict. This aid has broad humanitarian and societal impact, helping sustain Ukraine during war, and reflects a major international commitment with measurable benefits for millions affected by the war.
articles.personality_title: EU provides 2.3 billion euros more to support Ukraine during conflict
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For nearly four years, Ukraine has been defending itself against attacks from Russia. The European Union (EU) has been helping Ukraine since the war began in 2022 by providing money, military support, and aid for refugees.

**What happened** – The EU recently sent an additional 2.3 billion euros to Ukraine. This money is meant to help Ukraine’s public services and government run smoothly during the ongoing conflict. The funds come from the EU’s Ukraine Facility, which has a total of 50 billion euros set aside for support.

**Impact** – This new financial aid helps Ukraine keep its government working and supports public services that people rely on every day. The money also comes partly from interest earned on frozen Russian state assets, showing how the EU is using resources connected to the conflict to help Ukraine.

**What's next step** – The EU plans to continue providing support through programs like the Ukraine Facility and the European Recovery Instrument (ERA), which has around 18.1 billion euros available. This ongoing aid will help Ukraine manage the challenges of war and rebuild its country.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s latest 2.3 billion euro aid strengthens Ukraine’s government and public services amid ongoing conflict, showing continued international support.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE transfère 2,3 milliards d'euros supplémentaires pour soutenir l'Ukraine en guerre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis près de quatre ans, l'Ukraine se défend contre les attaques de la Russie. L'Union européenne (UE) aide l'Ukraine depuis le début de la guerre en 2022, en fournissant de l'argent, un soutien militaire et une aide aux réfugiés.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – L'UE a récemment envoyé 2,3 milliards d'euros supplémentaires à l'Ukraine. Cet argent doit aider les services publics et le gouvernement ukrainien à fonctionner normalement pendant le conflit. Ces fonds font partie du mécanisme de l'UE appelé Ukraine Facility, doté de 50 milliards d'euros.

**Impact** – Cette aide financière permet à l'Ukraine de maintenir ses services publics essentiels. L'argent provient en partie des intérêts gagnés sur des avoirs russes gelés, montrant comment l'UE utilise des ressources liées au conflit pour soutenir l'Ukraine.

**Prochaine étape** – L'UE continuera d'apporter son soutien via des programmes comme Ukraine Facility et l'Instrument européen pour la reprise (ERA), qui dispose d'environ 18,1 milliards d'euros. Cette aide continue aidera l'Ukraine à gérer la guerre et à reconstruire son pays.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L'aide récente de 2,3 milliards d'euros de l'UE renforce le gouvernement et les services publics ukrainiens en pleine guerre, illustrant un soutien international constant.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE transfiere 2,3 mil millones de euros más para apoyar a Ucrania durante el conflicto
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante casi cuatro años, Ucrania se ha defendido de los ataques de Rusia. La Unión Europea (UE) ha estado ayudando a Ucrania desde que comenzó la guerra en 2022, proporcionando dinero, apoyo militar y ayuda para los refugiados.

**Qué pasó** – La UE envió recientemente 2,3 mil millones de euros adicionales a Ucrania. Este dinero ayudará a que los servicios públicos y el gobierno funcionen bien durante el conflicto. Estos fondos provienen del programa de la UE llamado Ukraine Facility, que tiene un total de 50 mil millones de euros para apoyo.

**Impacto** – Esta nueva ayuda financiera permite que Ucrania mantenga sus servicios públicos y su gobierno funcionando. Parte del dinero proviene de los intereses ganados con activos rusos congelados, mostrando cómo la UE usa recursos relacionados con el conflicto para ayudar a Ucrania.

**Próximo paso** – La UE planea seguir apoyando a través de programas como Ukraine Facility y el Instrumento Europeo de Recuperación (ERA), que cuenta con unos 18,1 mil millones de euros. Esta ayuda continua ayudará a Ucrania a enfrentar la guerra y a reconstruir el país.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La última ayuda de 2,3 mil millones de euros de la UE fortalece el gobierno y los servicios públicos de Ucrania durante el conflicto, mostrando un apoyo internacional constante.
